content: Combine the garlic salt, lemon juice, and olive oil. Whisk the three ingredients together in a small bowl and transfer to a 1-gallon (4-liter) resealable plastic bag. You can also use a glass dish covered with aluminum foil instead of the plastic bag. Coat the salmon. Place the salmon in the marinade and seal the bag. Turn the bag several times to coat all sides of the salmon. If using a glass dish, turn the fillets in the marinade several times to coat all sides, then cover the dish with a lid or aluminum foil. Refrigerate for 30 minutes. Place the bag with the marinade and salmon fillets in the refrigerator for 30 minutes. Salmon, like all fish, is not as dense as red meats and poultry. As a result, it does not need to be marinaded for long in order to absorb flavor. Remove the salmon from the refrigerator at least 10 minutes prior to cooking. Doing so raises the temperature, allowing it to cook more evenly throughout. Preheat the oven to 400℉ (200℃) Prepare a baking sheet with shallow sides by covering it with nonstick aluminum foil. Coat the pan with nonstick cooking spray if you don't have aluminum foil on hand. Transfer the salmon to the prepared baking sheet. If the salmon fillets have skin on them, lay them skin-side down on the sheet. Position the fillets in a single layer, spaced evenly. Bake for 15 minutes. [1] Place the baking sheet on the middle rack in the oven and cook the salmon until done. When done, you should be able to easily flake the salmon apart with a fork. The middle should also be opaque. Serve at your desired temperature. Salmon fillets can be served warm out of the oven or after they have cooled to room temperature. Preheat the broiler. Allow the broiler to heat up for 5 to 10 minutes. Most broilers only have an "on" setting, but if yours has separate "high" and "low" settings, set the broiler to high. Transfer the fillets to a broiler pan. Place the fillets on the interior rack inside the pan with the skin-side facing down, if applicable. Arrange the fillets in a single layer and space them apart evenly. If desired, coat the rack with nonstick cooking spray before putting the salmon on it. This is usually unadvised for fatty meats, but not much will drip off the salmon as it cooks. As such, using cooking spray can drastically reduce the amount of salmon that gets stuck to the broiler pan rack. Broil for 10 to 12 minutes. [2] Place the broiler pan 5 1/2 inches (14 cm) away from the top heating element and cook the salmon until done. The salmon is done when you can effortlessly flake the fillets with a fork. The center should be opaque. You can turn the salmon once during cooking to ensure even browning, but it is not necessary. Moreover, flipping salmon fillets can be difficult to do and may cause the salmon to fall apart in the oven prematurely. Serve. Broiled salmon can be served hot out of the oven or at room temperature. Preheat the grill. You can use both gas and charcoal grills to prepare salmon fillets. If using a gas grill, preheat the grill to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (232 degrees Celsius). If using a charcoal grill, spread a layer of charcoal onto the bottom of the grill and light. Allow the coals to burn and smolder for 30 minutes. Wrap the salmon fillets in aluminum foil. Place each fillet in the center of a piece of aluminum foil. Bring the sides up and fold them together, sealing the packet. Press any raised aluminum foil flat. If using nonstick aluminum foil, place the salmon fillets on the nonstick side. Transfer the packets to the grill and cook for 14 to 16 minutes. [3] Flip the packets once, at the 7 or 8 minute mark, using grill tongs or a heat-proof spatula. Checking the fillets for doneness may be difficult since the foil will be hot to the touch. You may need to wait until after you pull the fish from the grill. If the fillets do not flake easily with a fork or if the center is not opaque, seal the foil again and return to the grill. Let sit before serving. Allow the salmon to sit off the grill and in their foil packets at room temperature for 5 minutes, then serve. Preheat a skillet or sauté pan over high heat. The pan should get hot, but it should not begin to smoke. If desired, you can spray a thin coating of cooking spray on the pan or coat it in 1 Tbsp (15 ml) of olive oil before heating it. This step is not necessary if you marinated the salmon fillets or brushed them with olive oil, though. Place the fish in the preheated pan. Cook for 3 minutes before flipping each fillet over and cooking for an additional 3 to 4 minutes. Use a fish spatula to turn the fish. Do not use tongs, since the salmon will likely break apart prematurely if handled with tongs during the cooking process. The salmon is done when you can flake the center apart with a fork and when the entire fillet is no longer translucent. Allow the salmon fillets to cool slightly before servings. After removing them from the heat, you should let the fillets rest at room temperature for 5 minutes before you serve them. Bring the water to a simmer on the stovetop. Place the water in a saucepan with tall sides. Heat over medium heat until the water starts to gently simmer. If desired, you can salt the water as it heats up. You can also add one chopped shallot or green onion and several flavorful sprigs of fresh dill, rosemary, or other herbs to the water. This is an especially common way to flavor poached salmon, and is actually more commonly used than marinating. Add the salmon fillets to the pan. If they still have skins, place the fillets skin-side down. Cover and cook for 5 to 10 minutes. [4] If the salmon flakes apart easily with a fork and is no longer translucent inside, it has finished cooking. Serve warm. Remove the salmon fillets from the heat and let rest for 3 to 5 minutes before serving.

<p>Salmon fillets are versatile and delicious, but they cook quickly and require a bit of technique to get right. They are generally prepared by baking, broiling, grilling, pan-searing, or poaching them. Adding a marinade is a common way to infuse the fish with extra flavor. Whether you're a novice in the kitchen or an experienced cook, there's no reason to fear salmon. Skip to Step 1 to marinate your salmon, and then move on to the appropriate following method depending on how you want to cook your salmon.</p>
<br/><p><b>Makes 4 servings</b></p>

<div class="section ingredients sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Ingredients">Ingredients</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="ingredients">
<ul>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_ce1a34b627ef6a0da82d2b7aa4a198e9" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_ce1a34b627ef6a0da82d2b7aa4a198e9" name="item_ce1a34b627ef6a0da82d2b7aa4a198e9_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">4 salmon fillets, 6-oz (170 g) each</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_03e3f9f3b6602f5304dfe6e76fcc4ba8" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_03e3f9f3b6602f5304dfe6e76fcc4ba8" name="item_03e3f9f3b6602f5304dfe6e76fcc4ba8_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">1/2 tsp (2.5 ml) garlic salt</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_f083a3ba54265a2e119cec586f4260ec" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_f083a3ba54265a2e119cec586f4260ec" name="item_f083a3ba54265a2e119cec586f4260ec_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">3 Tbsp (45 ml) lemon juice</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_e9fa8c811f3cc9e9775b30171fa68215" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_e9fa8c811f3cc9e9775b30171fa68215" name="item_e9fa8c811f3cc9e9775b30171fa68215_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">2 Tbsp (30 ml) olive oil</div>
</li>
<li><input class="css-checkbox" id="item_d20a0ca8e81fc91b15fd8d90735e633a" type="checkbox"/><label class="css-checkbox-label" for="item_d20a0ca8e81fc91b15fd8d90735e633a" name="item_d20a0ca8e81fc91b15fd8d90735e633a_lbl"></label><div class="checkbox-text">1 to 2 cups (250 to 500 ml) water (for poaching only)</div>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Marinating_the_Salmon_Fillets_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Marinating_the_Salmon_Fillets">Marinating the Salmon Fillets</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-1.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-1.jpg" height="485" id="img_ad3d3d3c19" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ad3d3d3c19')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-1.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Combine the garlic salt, lemon juice, and olive oil.</b> Whisk the three ingredients together in a small bowl and transfer to a 1-gallon (4-liter) resealable plastic bag.

<ul>
<li>You can also use a glass dish covered with aluminum foil instead of the plastic bag.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-2.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_57fa2b8384" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_57fa2b8384')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-2.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Coat the salmon.</b> Place the salmon in the marinade and seal the bag. Turn the bag several times to coat all sides of the salmon.

<ul>
<li>If using a glass dish, turn the fillets in the marinade several times to coat all sides, then cover the dish with a lid or aluminum foil.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-3.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-3.jpg" height="485" id="img_d1c658576a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d1c658576a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-3.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Refrigerate for 30 minutes.</b> Place the bag with the marinade and salmon fillets in the refrigerator for 30 minutes.

<ul>
<li>Salmon, like all fish, is not as dense as red meats and poultry. As a result, it does not need to be marinaded for long in order to absorb flavor.</li>
<li>Remove the salmon from the refrigerator at least 10 minutes prior to cooking. Doing so raises the temperature, allowing it to cook more evenly throughout.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Baking_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Baking">Baking</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-4.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-4.jpg" height="485" id="img_df9057e612" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_df9057e612')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-4.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Preheat the oven to 400℉ (200℃) Prepare a baking sheet with shallow sides by covering it with nonstick aluminum foil.</b>
<ul>
<li>Coat the pan with nonstick cooking spray if you don't have aluminum foil on hand.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-5.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-5.jpg" height="485" id="img_a5e4688ba4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a5e4688ba4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-5.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Transfer the salmon to the prepared baking sheet.</b> If the salmon fillets have skin on them, lay them skin-side down on the sheet.

<ul>
<li>Position the fillets in a single layer, spaced evenly.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-6.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-6.jpg" height="485" id="img_b685c7b954" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b685c7b954')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-6.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Bake for 15 minutes.</b><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> Place the baking sheet on the middle rack in the oven and cook the salmon until done.

<ul>
<li>When done, you should be able to easily flake the salmon apart with a fork. The middle should also be opaque.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-7.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-7.jpg" height="485" id="img_5f00fe8bfc" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5f00fe8bfc')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-7.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Serve at your desired temperature.</b> Salmon fillets can be served warm out of the oven or after they have cooled to room temperature.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Broiling_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Broiling">Broiling</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-8.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-8.jpg" height="485" id="img_0967b0980b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0967b0980b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-8.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Preheat the broiler.</b> Allow the broiler to heat up for 5 to 10 minutes.

<ul>
<li>Most broilers only have an "on" setting, but if yours has separate "high" and "low" settings, set the broiler to high.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-9.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-9.jpg" height="485" id="img_38a49df3b2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_38a49df3b2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-9.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Transfer the fillets to a broiler pan.</b> Place the fillets on the interior rack inside the pan with the skin-side facing down, if applicable.

<ul>
<li>Arrange the fillets in a single layer and space them apart evenly.</li>
<li>If desired, coat the rack with nonstick cooking spray before putting the salmon on it. This is usually unadvised for fatty meats, but not much will drip off the salmon as it cooks. As such, using cooking spray can drastically reduce the amount of salmon that gets stuck to the broiler pan rack.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-10.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-10.jpg" height="485" id="img_da8b473b38" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_da8b473b38')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-10.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Broil for 10 to 12 minutes.</b><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup> Place the broiler pan 5 1/2 inches (14 cm) away from the top heating element and cook the salmon until done.

<ul>
<li>The salmon is done when you can effortlessly flake the fillets with a fork. The center should be opaque.</li>
<li>You can turn the salmon once during cooking to ensure even browning, but it is not necessary. Moreover, flipping salmon fillets can be difficult to do and may cause the salmon to fall apart in the oven prematurely.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-11.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-11.jpg" height="485" id="img_515f4d465f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_515f4d465f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-11.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Serve.</b> Broiled salmon can be served hot out of the oven or at room temperature.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Grilling_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Grilling">Grilling</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-12.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-12.jpg" height="485" id="img_8719afbc60" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8719afbc60')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-12.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Preheat the grill.</b> You can use both gas and charcoal grills to prepare salmon fillets.

<ul>
<li>If using a gas grill, preheat the grill to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (232 degrees Celsius).</li>
<li>If using a charcoal grill, spread a layer of charcoal onto the bottom of the grill and light. Allow the coals to burn and smolder for 30 minutes.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-13.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-13.jpg" height="485" id="img_5964bfef25" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5964bfef25')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-13.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Wrap the salmon fillets in aluminum foil.</b> Place each fillet in the center of a piece of aluminum foil. Bring the sides up and fold them together, sealing the packet. Press any raised aluminum foil flat.

<ul>
<li>If using nonstick aluminum foil, place the salmon fillets on the nonstick side.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-14.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-14.jpg" height="485" id="img_9b39bc7477" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9b39bc7477')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-14.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Transfer the packets to the grill and cook for 14 to 16 minutes.</b><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Flip the packets once, at the 7 or 8 minute mark, using grill tongs or a heat-proof spatula.

<ul>
<li>Checking the fillets for doneness may be difficult since the foil will be hot to the touch. You may need to wait until after you pull the fish from the grill. If the fillets do not flake easily with a fork or if the center is not opaque, seal the foil again and return to the grill.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ea/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-15.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-15.jpg" height="485" id="img_8d127a931d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8d127a931d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ea/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-15.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Let sit before serving.</b> Allow the salmon to sit off the grill and in their foil packets at room temperature for 5 minutes, then serve.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Pan-Searing_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>5</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Pan-Searing">Pan-Searing</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_5">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-16.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-16.jpg" height="485" id="img_4d2a3fda86" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4d2a3fda86')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-16.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Preheat a skillet or sauté pan over high heat.</b> The pan should get hot, but it should not begin to smoke.

<ul>
<li>If desired, you can spray a thin coating of cooking spray on the pan or coat it in 1 Tbsp (15 ml) of olive oil before heating it. This step is not necessary if you marinated the salmon fillets or brushed them with olive oil, though.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-17.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-17.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-17.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-17.jpg" height="485" id="img_721b0c106e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_721b0c106e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-17.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-17.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Place the fish in the preheated pan.</b> Cook for 3 minutes before flipping each fillet over and cooking for an additional 3 to 4 minutes.

<ul>
<li>Use a fish spatula to turn the fish. Do not use tongs, since the salmon will likely break apart prematurely if handled with tongs during the cooking process.</li>
<li>The salmon is done when you can flake the center apart with a fork and when the entire fillet is no longer translucent.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-18.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-18.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-18.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-18.jpg" height="485" id="img_5104f58afe" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5104f58afe')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-18.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-18.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Allow the salmon fillets to cool slightly before servings.</b> After removing them from the heat, you should let the fillets rest at room temperature for 5 minutes before you serve them.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Poaching_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>6</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Poaching">Poaching</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_6">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-19.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-19.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-19.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-19.jpg" height="485" id="img_a9330afc6d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a9330afc6d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-19.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-19.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_6_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Bring the water to a simmer on the stovetop.</b> Place the water in a saucepan with tall sides. Heat over medium heat until the water starts to gently simmer.

<ul>
<li>If desired, you can salt the water as it heats up. You can also add one chopped shallot or green onion and several flavorful sprigs of fresh dill, rosemary, or other herbs to the water. This is an especially common way to flavor poached salmon, and is actually more commonly used than marinating.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-20.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-20.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 20" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-20.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-20.jpg" height="485" id="img_7f344d45d0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7f344d45d0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 20" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-20.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-20.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_6_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add the salmon fillets to the pan.</b> If they still have skins, place the fillets skin-side down. Cover and cook for 5 to 10 minutes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If the salmon flakes apart easily with a fork and is no longer translucent inside, it has finished cooking.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-21.jpg?ajax=true&aid=2535837" href="#/Image:Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-21.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 21" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/36/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-21.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-21.jpg" height="485" id="img_02d800b470" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_02d800b470')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cook Salmon Fillet Step 21" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/36/Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-21.jpg/aid2535837-v4-728px-Cook-Salmon-Fillet-Step-21.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_6_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Serve warm.</b> Remove the salmon fillets from the heat and let rest for 3 to 5 minutes before serving.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="2535837" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="399791" data-caid="400664" data-cqid="399808" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1223843" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What do I coat salmon with after it's cooked?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You can coat it with anything, it's up to you, but I would recommend butter sauce, lemon sauce or parsley sauce. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="39845" data-caid="40718" data-cqid="39862" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="283291" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="9" data-votes_up="23">

<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can I freeze salmon after cooking?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">

<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You can freeze cooked salmon. Freezing salmon can be a bit tricky, so it’s best to take your time and prepare the fish first for best results. Fish that’s been frozen and then thawed can sometimes have a strong smell, but it’s less of a problem with cooked fish. Still, you may want to make sure that you place it in a part of the freezer where it won’t be in contact with another food that may take on a fishy smell.</div>

<table width="375px"><tr>
<td><br/></td>
<td align="left">This does not follow the recipe precisely, but provides an easy way of cooking delicious salmon.</td>
</tr></table>

<div class="clearall"></div>

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>If desired, you can prepare a second, separate batch of the marinade and use it as a sauce or glaze. To use it as a glaze, coat grilled, pan-seared, or broiled salmon halfway through the cooking process with the mixture using a pastry brush. To use it as a sauce, thicken it on the stovetop by cooking the marinade over medium-high heat until it reduces and thickens.</li>
<li>If baking or pan-searing the salmon fillets, you could also skip the marinade and coat the fish with a layer of fresh herbs, such as parsley, basil, and dill.</li>
<li>Experiment with the marinade ingredients as desired, using different combinations of oil, acid, and seasoning. Acids usually include vinegars and citrus juices, and seasonings can be dry or wet. For instance, you could create a marinade using soy sauce, rice vinegar, olive oil, and brown sugar. You could also use a vinaigrette dressing, which already combines vinegar, cooking oil, and seasonings.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

</h2>
<p>The simplest way to cook a salmon fillet is to heat a pan with oil on high heat and fry the fillet for 3 minutes on each side. If you want to bake the fillet, marinate it for 30 minutes in the refrigerator, preheat the oven to 400 degrees, and bake for 15 minutes. <span id="summary_last_sentence">Keep reading to learn how to grill fillets in foil, poach, and broil them!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Marinating the Salmon Fillets",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Combine the garlic salt, lemon juice, and olive oil. Whisk the three ingredients together in a small bowl and transfer to a 1-gallon (4-liter) resealable plastic bag.\n\nYou can also use a glass dish covered with aluminum foil instead of the plastic bag."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Coat the salmon. Place the salmon in the marinade and seal the bag. Turn the bag several times to coat all sides of the salmon.\n\nIf using a glass dish, turn the fillets in the marinade several times to coat all sides, then cover the dish with a lid or aluminum foil."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Refrigerate for 30 minutes. Place the bag with the marinade and salmon fillets in the refrigerator for 30 minutes.\n\nSalmon, like all fish, is not as dense as red meats and poultry. As a result, it does not need to be marinaded for long in order to absorb flavor.\nRemove the salmon from the refrigerator at least 10 minutes prior to cooking. Doing so raises the temperature, allowing it to cook more evenly throughout."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Baking",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u2109 (200\u2103) Prepare a baking sheet with shallow sides by covering it with nonstick aluminum foil.\n\nCoat the pan with nonstick cooking spray if you don't have aluminum foil on hand."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Transfer the salmon to the prepared baking sheet. If the salmon fillets have skin on them, lay them skin-side down on the sheet.\n\nPosition the fillets in a single layer, spaced evenly."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Bake for 15 minutes.[1] Place the baking sheet on the middle rack in the oven and cook the salmon until done.\n\nWhen done, you should be able to easily flake the salmon apart with a fork. The middle should also be opaque."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Serve at your desired temperature. Salmon fillets can be served warm out of the oven or after they have cooled to room temperature."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Broiling",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Preheat the broiler. Allow the broiler to heat up for 5 to 10 minutes.\n\nMost broilers only have an \"on\" setting, but if yours has separate \"high\" and \"low\" settings, set the broiler to high."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Transfer the fillets to a broiler pan. Place the fillets on the interior rack inside the pan with the skin-side facing down, if applicable.\n\nArrange the fillets in a single layer and space them apart evenly.\nIf desired, coat the rack with nonstick cooking spray before putting the salmon on it. This is usually unadvised for fatty meats, but not much will drip off the salmon as it cooks. As such, using cooking spray can drastically reduce the amount of salmon that gets stuck to the broiler pan rack."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Broil for 10 to 12 minutes.[2] Place the broiler pan 5 1\/2 inches (14 cm) away from the top heating element and cook the salmon until done.\n\nThe salmon is done when you can effortlessly flake the fillets with a fork. The center should be opaque.\nYou can turn the salmon once during cooking to ensure even browning, but it is not necessary. Moreover, flipping salmon fillets can be difficult to do and may cause the salmon to fall apart in the oven prematurely."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Serve. Broiled salmon can be served hot out of the oven or at room temperature."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Grilling",
            "position": 4,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Preheat the grill. You can use both gas and charcoal grills to prepare salmon fillets.\n\nIf using a gas grill, preheat the grill to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (232 degrees Celsius).\nIf using a charcoal grill, spread a layer of charcoal onto the bottom of the grill and light. Allow the coals to burn and smolder for 30 minutes."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Wrap the salmon fillets in aluminum foil. Place each fillet in the center of a piece of aluminum foil. Bring the sides up and fold them together, sealing the packet. Press any raised aluminum foil flat.\n\nIf using nonstick aluminum foil, place the salmon fillets on the nonstick side."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Transfer the packets to the grill and cook for 14 to 16 minutes.[3] Flip the packets once, at the 7 or 8 minute mark, using grill tongs or a heat-proof spatula.\n\nChecking the fillets for doneness may be difficult since the foil will be hot to the touch. You may need to wait until after you pull the fish from the grill. If the fillets do not flake easily with a fork or if the center is not opaque, seal the foil again and return to the grill."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Let sit before serving. Allow the salmon to sit off the grill and in their foil packets at room temperature for 5 minutes, then serve."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Pan-Searing",
            "position": 5,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Preheat a skillet or saut\u00e9 pan over high heat. The pan should get hot, but it should not begin to smoke.\n\nIf desired, you can spray a thin coating of cooking spray on the pan or coat it in 1 Tbsp (15 ml) of olive oil before heating it. This step is not necessary if you marinated the salmon fillets or brushed them with olive oil, though."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Place the fish in the preheated pan. Cook for 3 minutes before flipping each fillet over and cooking for an additional 3 to 4 minutes.\n\nUse a fish spatula to turn the fish. Do not use tongs, since the salmon will likely break apart prematurely if handled with tongs during the cooking process.\nThe salmon is done when you can flake the center apart with a fork and when the entire fillet is no longer translucent."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Allow the salmon fillets to cool slightly before servings. After removing them from the heat, you should let the fillets rest at room temperature for 5 minutes before you serve them."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Poaching",
            "position": 6,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Bring the water to a simmer on the stovetop. Place the water in a saucepan with tall sides. Heat over medium heat until the water starts to gently simmer.\n\nIf desired, you can salt the water as it heats up. You can also add one chopped shallot or green onion and several flavorful sprigs of fresh dill, rosemary, or other herbs to the water. This is an especially common way to flavor poached salmon, and is actually more commonly used than marinating."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Add the salmon fillets to the pan. If they still have skins, place the fillets skin-side down. Cover and cook for 5 to 10 minutes.[4]\nIf the salmon flakes apart easily with a fork and is no longer translucent inside, it has finished cooking."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Serve warm. Remove the salmon fillets from the heat and let rest for 3 to 5 minutes before serving."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],

title: How to Cook Salmon Fillet
content_html:
Combine the garlic salt, lemon juice, and olive oil. Whisk the three ingredients together in a small bowl and transfer to a 1-gallon (4-liter) resealable plastic bag.
  • You can also use a glass dish covered with aluminum foil instead of the plastic bag.
Coat the salmon. Place the salmon in the marinade and seal the bag. Turn the bag several times to coat all sides of the salmon.
  • If using a glass dish, turn the fillets in the marinade several times to coat all sides, then cover the dish with a lid or aluminum foil.
Refrigerate for 30 minutes. Place the bag with the marinade and salmon fillets in the refrigerator for 30 minutes.
  • Salmon, like all fish, is not as dense as red meats and poultry. As a result, it does not need to be marinaded for long in order to absorb flavor.
  • Remove the salmon from the refrigerator at least 10 minutes prior to cooking. Doing so raises the temperature, allowing it to cook more evenly throughout.
Preheat the oven to 400℉ (200℃) Prepare a baking sheet with shallow sides by covering it with nonstick aluminum foil.
  • Coat the pan with nonstick cooking spray if you don't have aluminum foil on hand.
Transfer the salmon to the prepared baking sheet. If the salmon fillets have skin on them, lay them skin-side down on the sheet.
  • Position the fillets in a single layer, spaced evenly.
Bake for 15 minutes.[1] Place the baking sheet on the middle rack in the oven and cook the salmon until done.
  • When done, you should be able to easily flake the salmon apart with a fork. The middle should also be opaque.
Serve at your desired temperature. Salmon fillets can be served warm out of the oven or after they have cooled to room temperature.
Preheat the broiler. Allow the broiler to heat up for 5 to 10 minutes.
  • Most broilers only have an "on" setting, but if yours has separate "high" and "low" settings, set the broiler to high.
Transfer the fillets to a broiler pan. Place the fillets on the interior rack inside the pan with the skin-side facing down, if applicable.
  • Arrange the fillets in a single layer and space them apart evenly.
  • If desired, coat the rack with nonstick cooking spray before putting the salmon on it. This is usually unadvised for fatty meats, but not much will drip off the salmon as it cooks. As such, using cooking spray can drastically reduce the amount of salmon that gets stuck to the broiler pan rack.
Broil for 10 to 12 minutes.[2] Place the broiler pan 5 1/2 inches (14 cm) away from the top heating element and cook the salmon until done.
  • The salmon is done when you can effortlessly flake the fillets with a fork. The center should be opaque.
  • You can turn the salmon once during cooking to ensure even browning, but it is not necessary. Moreover, flipping salmon fillets can be difficult to do and may cause the salmon to fall apart in the oven prematurely.
Serve. Broiled salmon can be served hot out of the oven or at room temperature.
Preheat the grill. You can use both gas and charcoal grills to prepare salmon fillets.
  • If using a gas grill, preheat the grill to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (232 degrees Celsius).
  • If using a charcoal grill, spread a layer of charcoal onto the bottom of the grill and light. Allow the coals to burn and smolder for 30 minutes.
Wrap the salmon fillets in aluminum foil. Place each fillet in the center of a piece of aluminum foil. Bring the sides up and fold them together, sealing the packet. Press any raised aluminum foil flat.
  • If using nonstick aluminum foil, place the salmon fillets on the nonstick side.
Transfer the packets to the grill and cook for 14 to 16 minutes.[3] Flip the packets once, at the 7 or 8 minute mark, using grill tongs or a heat-proof spatula.
  • Checking the fillets for doneness may be difficult since the foil will be hot to the touch. You may need to wait until after you pull the fish from the grill. If the fillets do not flake easily with a fork or if the center is not opaque, seal the foil again and return to the grill.
Let sit before serving. Allow the salmon to sit off the grill and in their foil packets at room temperature for 5 minutes, then serve.
Preheat a skillet or sauté pan over high heat. The pan should get hot, but it should not begin to smoke.
  • If desired, you can spray a thin coating of cooking spray on the pan or coat it in 1 Tbsp (15 ml) of olive oil before heating it. This step is not necessary if you marinated the salmon fillets or brushed them with olive oil, though.
Place the fish in the preheated pan. Cook for 3 minutes before flipping each fillet over and cooking for an additional 3 to 4 minutes.
  • Use a fish spatula to turn the fish. Do not use tongs, since the salmon will likely break apart prematurely if handled with tongs during the cooking process.
  • The salmon is done when you can flake the center apart with a fork and when the entire fillet is no longer translucent.
Allow the salmon fillets to cool slightly before servings. After removing them from the heat, you should let the fillets rest at room temperature for 5 minutes before you serve them.
Bring the water to a simmer on the stovetop. Place the water in a saucepan with tall sides. Heat over medium heat until the water starts to gently simmer.
  • If desired, you can salt the water as it heats up. You can also add one chopped shallot or green onion and several flavorful sprigs of fresh dill, rosemary, or other herbs to the water. This is an especially common way to flavor poached salmon, and is actually more commonly used than marinating.
Add the salmon fillets to the pan. If they still have skins, place the fillets skin-side down. Cover and cook for 5 to 10 minutes.[4]
  • If the salmon flakes apart easily with a fork and is no longer translucent inside, it has finished cooking.
Serve warm. Remove the salmon fillets from the heat and let rest for 3 to 5 minutes before serving.
